===Controversies=== In 2017, Nature published an editorial entitled "Removing Statues of Historical figures risks whitewashing history: Science must acknowledge mistakes as it marks its past". The article commented on the placement and maintenance of statues honouring scientists with known unethical, abusive and torturous histories. Specifically, the editorial called on examples of [[J. Marion Sims]], the 'Father of gynecology' who experimented on African American female slaves who were unable to give informed consent, and [[Thomas Parran Jr.]] who oversaw the [[Tuskegee syphilis experiment]]. The editorial as written made the case that removing such statues, and erasing names, runs the risk of "whitewashing history", and stated “Instead of removing painful reminders, perhaps these should be supplemented”. The article caused a large outcry and was quickly modified by Nature.<ref>{{cite web |title=Science must acknowledge its past mistakes and crimes |date=4 September 2017 |url=https://www.nature.com/news/science-must-acknowledge-its-past-mistakes-and-crimes-1.22557?sf111543858=1&WT.mc_id=TWT_NatureNews |website=nature.com}}</ref> The article was largely seen as offensive, inappropriate, and by many, racist. Nature acknowledged that the article as originally written was "offensive and poorly worded" and published selected letters of response.<ref>{{cite web |title=Readers respond to Nature’s Editorial on historical monuments |date=8 September 2017 |url=http://www.nature.com/news/readers-respond-to-nature-s-editorial-on-historical-monuments-1.22584 |website=nature.com}}</ref> The editorial came just weeks after hundreds of white supremacists marched in [[Charlottesville, Virginia]] in the [[Unite the Right Rally|Unite the Right rally]] to oppose the removal of [[Robert Edward Lee Sculpture|a statue of Robert E. Lee]], setting off violence in the streets and killing a young woman. When Nature posted a link to the editorial on [[Twitter]], the thread quickly exploded with criticisms. In response, several scientists called for a boycott.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Schulson |first=Michael |title=History Lessons for ‘Nature’|date=17 September 2017 |newspaper=Undark Magazine |url=https://undark.org/article/nature-journal-j-marion-sims/}}</ref> On 18 September 2017, the editorial was updated and edited by Philip Campbell, the editor of the journal.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Campbell |first=Philip |title=Statues: An Editorial Response|date= 18 September 2017 |newspaper=Nature |url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/vaop/ncurrent/full/549334c.html}}</ref>
When [[Paul Lauterbur]] and [[Peter Mansfield]] won a [[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine]] for research initially rejected by ''Nature'' and published only after Lauterbur appealed the rejection, ''Nature'' acknowledged more of its own missteps in rejecting papers in an editorial titled, "Coping with Peer Rejection": {{quote|[T]here are unarguable ''faux pas'' in our history. These include the rejection of [[Čherenkov radiation|Cherenkov radiation]], [[Hideki Yukawa]]'s [[meson]], work on [[photosynthesis]] by [[Johann Deisenhofer]], [[Robert Huber]] and [[Hartmut Michel]], and the initial rejection (but eventual acceptance) of [[Stephen Hawking]]'s [[Hawking radiation|black-hole radiation]].<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v425/n6959/full/425645a.html |journal=Nature |date=16 October 2003 |title=Coping with peer rejection |volume=425 |page=645 |doi=10.1038/425645a |pmid=14562060 |issue=6959 |bibcode=2003Natur.425..645.}}</ref>}}
From 2000 to 2001, a series of five fraudulent papers by [[Schön scandal|Jan Hendrik Schön]] was published in ''Nature''. The papers, about [[semiconductors]], were revealed to contain falsified data and other scientific fraud. In 2003, ''Nature'' retracted the papers. The Schön scandal was not limited to ''Nature''; other prominent journals, such as ''[[Science (journal)|Science]]'' and ''[[Physical Review]]'', also retracted papers by Schön.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v422/n6927/index.html |journal=Nature |date=6 March 2003 |title=Retractions' realities |volume=422 |issue=6927 |page=1 |doi=10.1038/422001a |pmid=12621394}}</ref>
In June 1988, after nearly a year of guided scrutiny from its editors, ''Nature'' published a controversial and seemingly anomalous paper detailing Dr. [[Jacques Benveniste]] and his team's work studying human [[Basophil granulocyte|basophil]] [[degranulation]] in the presence of extremely dilute [[antibody]] serum.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://vet-servis.ru/downloads/nature333-30-1988.pdf |title=vet-servis.ru |publisher=Vet-servis.ru |date= |accessdate=2014-05-01 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> In short, their paper concluded that less than a single molecule of antibody could trigger an immune response in human basophils, defying the physical [[law of mass action]]. The paper excited substantial media attention in Paris, chiefly because their research sought funding from [[homeopathic]] medicine companies. Public inquiry prompted ''Nature'' to mandate an extensive, stringent and scientifically questionable experimental [[replication (statistics)|replication]] in Benveniste's lab, through which his team's results were categorically refuted.<ref>{{cite journal | title = "High-dilution" experiments a delusion | volume = 334 | issue = 6180 | journal = Nature | pages = 287–291 | year = 1988 | pmid = 2455869 | last1 = Maddox | first1 = J. | last2 = Randi | first2 = J. | last3 = Stewart | first3 = W. | doi = 10.1038/334287a0 | bibcode = 1988Natur.334..287M }}</ref>
Before publishing one of its most famous discoveries, [[James D. Watson|Watson]] and [[Francis Crick|Crick]]'s 1953 [[Molecular Structure of Nucleic Acids: A Structure for Deoxyribose Nucleic Acid|paper]] on the [[structure of DNA]], ''Nature'' did not send the paper out for peer review. [[John Maddox]], ''Nature''{{'}}s editor, stated: "the Watson and Crick paper was not peer-reviewed by ''Nature'' ... the paper could not have been refereed: its correctness is self-evident. No referee working in the field ... could have kept his mouth shut once he saw the structure".<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Maddox |first1=J. |doi=10.1038/426119b |title=How genius can smooth the road to publication |journal=Nature |volume=426 |issue=6963 |page=119 |year=2003|bibcode=2003Natur.426..119M }}</ref>
An earlier error occurred when [[Enrico Fermi]] submitted his breakthrough paper on the weak [[Fermi's interaction|interaction theory]] of [[beta decay]]. ''Nature'' turned down the paper because it was considered too remote from reality.<ref>{{cite book|author=Rhodes, Richard |title=The Making of the Atomic Bomb|publisher= Touchstone|location= New York|date= 1986|isbn= 0-671-44133-7}}</ref> Fermi's paper was published by ''[[Zeitschrift für Physik]]'' in 1934,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Fermi |first1=E. |title=Versuch einer Theorie der β-Strahlen. I |journal=Zeitschrift für Physik |volume=88 |issue=3–4 |pages=161–177 |year=1934 |doi=10.1007/BF01351864 |bibcode=1934ZPhy...88..161F}}</ref> and finally published by ''Nature'' five years later,{{citation needed|date=March 2011}} after Fermi's work had been widely accepted.
==Science fiction== In 1999 ''Nature'' began publishing [[science fiction]] [[short stories]]. The brief "[[vignette (literature)|vignettes]]" are printed in a series called "Futures". The stories appeared in 1999 and 2000, again in 2005 and 2006, and have appeared weekly since July 2007.<ref name="futures">{{cite web | url=http://www.nature.com/nature/focus/arts/futures/ | title=Futures | work=Nature | accessdate=9 August 2012}}</ref> Sister publication ''[[Nature Physics]]'' also printed stories in 2007 and 2008.<ref name="FuturesPhysics">{{cite web |url= http://www.nature.com/nphys/archive/categ_fut_012008.html |title=Futures Archive |work= [[Nature Physics]] |accessdate= 2014-05-01 }}</ref> In 2005, ''Nature'' was awarded the [[European Science Fiction Society]]'s Best Publisher award for the "Futures" series.<ref name="ESFSAward">{{cite web |url= http://www.esfs.info/esfs-awards-2000.html#2005 |title= The ESFS Awards, Eurocon 2005: Glasgow – Scotland |author= [[European Science Fiction Society]] }}</ref> One hundred of the ''Nature'' stories between 1999 and 2006 were published as the collection ''Futures from Nature'' in 2008.<ref name="FuturesCollection">{{cite book |url= http://www.tor-forge.com/futuresfromnature |title= Futures from Nature: 100 Speculative fictions from the pages of the leading science journal |editor= Henry Gee |publisher= [[Tor Books]] |date= 2008 |location= New York City |isbn= 0-7653-1805-9 |quote= With stories from: [[Arthur C. Clarke]], [[Bruce Sterling]], [[Charles Stross]], [[Cory Doctorow]], [[Greg Bear]], [[Gregory Benford]], [[Oliver Morton (science writer)|Oliver Morton]], [[Ian R. MacLeod]], [[Rudy Rucker]], [[Greg Egan]], [[Stephen Baxter (author)|Stephen Baxter]], [[Barrington J. Bayley]], [[Brian Stableford]], [[Frederik Pohl]], [[Vernor Vinge]], [[Nancy Kress]], [[Michael Moorcock]], [[Vonda McIntyre]], [[Kim Stanley Robinson]], [[John M. Ford]] and eighty more. |access-date= 10 August 2012 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20081007211318/http://www.tor-forge.com/futuresfromnature |archive-date= 7 October 2008 |dead-url= yes |df= dmy-all }}</ref>
==Publication == [[File:Nature Materials Nov 2008.jpg|thumb|upright|''[[Nature Materials]],'' a specialized journal from [[Nature Publishing Group]].]] The journal has a weekly circulation of around 53,000 and a pass-along rate of 8.0,<ref>{{Citation |title=Demographics: Nature |url=http://www.nature.com/advertising/resources/pdf/2010naturemediakit.pdf?prod_code=NATURE&prod=Nature |website=nature.com |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110513233735/http://www.nature.com/advertising/resources/pdf/2010naturemediakit.pdf?prod_code=NATURE&prod=Nature |archivedate=2011-05-13}}, a profile of Nature's readership.</ref> resulting in a readership of over 400,000.<ref>{{cite web |title=Selling Your Publication — Circulation vs. Readership |url=http://www.ads-on-line.com/newbasiccourse/products/ |date=2013 |publisher=McInnis & Associates}}</ref>
''Nature'' is edited and published in the United Kingdom by a division of the international [[scientific publishing]] company [[Springer Nature]] that publishes [[academic journal]]s, [[magazine]]s, online databases, and services in science and medicine. ''Nature'' has offices in London, New York City, San Francisco, Washington, D.C., [[Boston]], Tokyo, Hong Kong, Paris, [[Munich]], and [[Basingstoke]]. Nature Publishing Group also publishes other specialized journals including ''[[Nature Neuroscience]]'', ''[[Nature Biotechnology]],'' ''[[Nature Methods]]'', the ''[[Nature Clinical Practice]]'' series of journals, ''[[Nature Structural & Molecular Biology]]'', ''[[Nature Chemistry]]'', and the ''Nature Reviews'' series of journals.
Since 2005, each issue of ''Nature'' has been accompanied by a ''[[Nature Podcast]]''<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.nature.com/nature/podcast/archive.html | work = Nature |title = Archive: Nature Podcast |accessdate = 2014-05-01 }}</ref> featuring highlights from the issue and interviews with the articles' authors and the journalists covering the research. It is presented by Kerri Smith, and features interviews with scientists on the latest research, as well as news reports from Nature's editors and journalists. The Nature Podcast was founded – and the first 100 episodes were produced and presented – by clinician and virologist [[Chris Smith, The Naked Scientist|Chris Smith]] of Cambridge and ''[[The Naked Scientists]]''.
In 2007, Nature Publishing Group began publishing ''Clinical Pharmacology & Therapeutics'', the official journal of the American Society of Clinical Pharmacology & Therapeutics and ''Molecular Therapy'', the American Society of Gene Therapy's official journal, as well as the ''International Society for Microbial Ecology (ISME) Journal''. Nature Publishing Group launched ''Nature Photonics'' in 2007 and ''Nature Geoscience'' in 2008. ''Nature Chemistry'' published its first issue in April 2009.
Nature Publishing Group actively supports the self-archiving process and in 2002 was one of the first publishers to allow authors to post their contributions on their personal websites, by requesting an exclusive licence to publish, rather than requiring authors to transfer copyright. In December 2007, Nature Publishing Group introduced the Creative Commons attribution-non commercial-share alike unported licence for those articles in Nature journals that are publishing the primary sequence of an organism's genome for the first time.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.itconversations.com/shows/detail1864.html |title=Interview with Timo Hannay, director of web publishing for Nature Publishing Group |work=Jon Udell's Interviews with Innovators |date=2007-07-05}}</ref>
In 2008, a collection of articles from ''Nature'' was edited by John S. Partington under the title ''H. G. Wells in Nature, 1893–1946: A Reception Reader'' and published by Peter Lang.<ref>{{cite book|author=Partington, John S. |year=2008 |title=H. G. Wells in Nature, 1893–1946: A Reception Reader |place=Frankfurt |publisher=Peter Lang |isbn=3631571100}}</ref>

[[Image:6DS4NuvistorVacuumTube.jpg|thumb|right|upright|RCA 6DS4 "Nuvistor" triode vacuum tube, ca. 20 mm high and 11 mm in diameter.]] [[Image:Nuvistor 530.jpg|thumb|upright|right|Nuvistor with U.S. dime for scale]]
The '''nuvistor''' is a type of [[vacuum tube]] announced by [[RCA]] in 1959. Most nuvistors are basically [[thimble]]-shaped, but somewhat smaller than a thimble, and much smaller than conventional tubes of the day, almost approaching the compactness of early discrete transistor casings. [[Triode]]s and a few [[tetrode]]s were made. The tube is made entirely of metal and ceramic. Making nuvistors requires special equipment, since there is no intubation to pump gases out of the envelope. Instead, the entire structure is assembled, inserted into its metal envelope, sealed and processed in a large vacuum chamber with simple robotic devices.
Nuvistors are among the highest performing small signal receiving tubes. They feature excellent VHF and UHF performance plus low noise figures, and were widely used throughout the 1960s in [[television set]]s (beginning with RCA's "New Vista" line of color sets in 1961 with the CTC-11 chassis), radio and high-fidelity equipment primarily in RF sections, and oscilloscopes. They competed with the [[solid state (electronics)|solid state]] revolution, and along with GE's [[Compactron]], probably held it at bay for a few years. RCA discontinued their use in television tuners for its product line in late 1971. One famous application was in the [[Ampex]] MR-70, a costly studio tape recorder whose entire electronics section was based on nuvistors. Another limited application of this very small tube was in studio-grade microphones from that era, the AKG/Norelco C12a, which employed the 7586, being a good example. It was also later found that, with minor circuit modification, the nuvistor made a sufficient replacement for the obsolete Telefunken VF14 tube, used in the famed Neumann [[U 47]] studio [[microphone]].<ref>[http://www.telefunken-elektroakustik.com/products/show_product.php?item=12 Telefunken: TELEFUNKEN U47M (EF14)]</ref>. Tektronix also used nuvistors in several of its high end oscilloscopes of the 1960s<ref>http://w140.com/tekwiki/wiki/Nuvistor TekWiki Nuvistor article</ref>, before replacing them later with [[JFET]] transistors.
==Types== * 7586 - First one released, medium mu triode * 7587 - Sharp cutoff tetrode * 8056 - triode for low plate voltages * 8058 - triode, with plate cap & grid on shell, for UHF performance * 7895 - 7586 with higher mu * 2CW4 - Same as type 6CW4, but with a 2.1 volt / 450 milliampere heater. Used in television receivers with series heater strings * 6CW4 - high mu triode, most common one in consumer electronics * 6DS4 - remote cutoff 6CW4 * 6DV4 - medium mu, intended as UHF oscillator, shell sometimes gold plated * 8393 - medium mu, used in Tektronix scopes (12.6 volt filament) * 13CW4 - same as 6CW4, but with 12.6 Volt / 230 milliampere heater

{{Infobox power station | name = Orapa Power Station {{Location map|Botswana |width = 280 |float = right |alt = Orapa Power Station |label = Orapa Power Station |position = right |mark = Green pog.svg |lat_deg = 21 |lat_min = 19 |lat_sec = 6 |lat_dir = S |lon_deg = 25 |lon_min = 25 |lon_sec = 3 |lon_dir = E }} | name_official = | image = | image_size = | image_caption = | image_alt = | location_map = Botswana | location_map_size = | location_map_caption= | coordinates = {{coord|21|19|06|S|25|25|03|E|region:BW_scale:50000|format=dms|display=title}} | coordinates_ref = | country = [[Botswana]] | location = [[Orapa]]
[[Central District (Botswana)|Central District]] | status = Operational | construction_began = | commissioned = 2011[https://www.kse-africa.com/project/orapa-power-plant Orapa Power Plant] | decommissioned = | cost = | owner = | operator = [[Botswana Power Corporation]] | solar_type = | solar_csp_technology= | th_fuel_primary = [[Natural_gas|Natural Gas]][http://www.tlouenergy.com.au/pdfs/12_01_31%20Tlou%20Orapa%20Power%20Station%20Report.pdf Orapa Power Station Report] | th_fuel_tertiary = [[Diesel_fuel|Diesel]] | ps_units_manu_model = [[GE LM6000]] Sprint [[Simple_cycle_combustion_turbine|Simple Cycle]] | th_cogeneration = | th_combined_cycle = | ps_electrical_capacity= 90 [[Megawatt|MW]] | ps_electrical_cap_fac= | ps_annual_generation= N/A ([[Peaking power plant]]) | website = [http://www.bpc.bw http://www.bpc.bw] | extra = }} The '''Orapa Power Station''' is a [[Peaking power plant|Peak load power generation plant]] located in the mining town of [[Orapa]] in northeastern [[Botswana]] in the [[Central District (Botswana)|Central District]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.mmegi.bw/index.php?sid=4&aid=587&dir=2011/October/Monday10/|title=Mmegi Online :: Orapa power plant to be finally launched|work=Mmegi Online|access-date=2018-09-29}} It is built within the [[Debswana|Debswana Diamond Company Ltd]] [[Orapa diamond mine]] [[lease|fenced leased area]] and is operated by the [[Botswana Power Corporation]]. ==Background== The plant construction was initiated when [[Botswana]] started experiencing electricity supply challenges from year '''2007''' when demand for electricity in the [[country]] started exceeding the county's electricity generation capacity leading to forced periodic nation wide [[Rolling_blackout|load shedding]] excises by the [[Botswana Power Corporation]]. The plant was a short term response to the mining industry electricity requirements[http://www.mmegi.bw/index.php?sid=4&aid=5796&dir=2010/October/Friday22 Developers of Orapa's 90MW push for 60 % cost reduction] prior to the development of Mmamabula and Morupule B power stations. The plant site is located next to an [[electrical substation]] through which it connects to the [[Electrical grid|national grid]] and was designed to use either [[natural gas]] or [[Diesel_fuel|diesel]] as [[fuel]]. It was commissioned using [[Diesel_fuel|diesel]] with a planned conversion to [[natural gas]] once construction of a [[Pipeline transport|gas pipeline]] from nearby [[Coalbed methane|gas fields]] was complete and commissioned.[http://www.sundaystandard.info/kalahari-energy-convert-diesel-orapa-power-plant-cbm-operation Kalahari Energy to convert diesel Orapa Power Plant to CBM operation] ==Specifications== The plant consists of two 45MW [[GE LM6000]] Sprint [[Simple_cycle_combustion_turbine|Simple Cycle]] [[gas turbines]] fueled using [[Diesel_fuel|diesel]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.sundaystandard.info/bpc-gets-orapa-90mw-power-station|title=BPC gets Orapa 90MW Power Station {{!}} Sunday Standard|website=www.sundaystandard.info|access-date=2018-09-29}} The energy produced is transferred to the [[Electrical grid|national grid]] via the interconnected Orapa Substation by use of two short [[Electric power transmission|132kV overhead power lines]]. == See also == {{stack|{{Portal|Botswana}}}} *[[List of power stations in Botswana]] *[[List of natural gas power stations]] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Energy]] {{improve categories|date=September 2018}}

{{Use New Zealand English|date=April 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}} {{Infobox person |name = Captain Pete Bethune |image = PeterBethune with Earthrace.JPG |image_size = |caption = Peter Bethune with Earthrace |birth_name = Peter James Bethune |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1965|04|04|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Hamilton, New Zealand|Hamilton]], New Zealand |death_date = |death_place = |death_cause = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = |education = [[Bachelor of Engineering]], [[Bachelor of Science]], [[Master of Business Administration]] |alma_mater = [[University of Auckland]], [[University of Waikato]], [[Macquarie Graduate School of Management]] |occupation = [[Captain]], [[CEO]], [[Television producer|Producer]], [[Author]] |employer = Earthrace Charitable Trust |known_for = |home_town = |salary = |networth = |height = |weight = |title =Captain |term = |predecessor = |successor = |party = |boards = |spouse = Sharyn Bethune (married in 1993)-Divorced |partner = |children = 2 daughters (Danielle and Alycia Bethune) |parents = Don Bethune (Father), Betty Bethune (Mother) |relations = |website = [http://www.earthrace.net Earthrace] |signature = |footnotes = |religion = }} Captain '''Peter James Bethune''' (born 4 April 1965) is a New Zealand ship's [[Sea captain|captain]] with 500 ton master licence, [[Publishing|published]] [[author]], producer of ''The Operatives'' [[Television program|TV Show]], and [[Public speaking|public speaker]]. He is the founder of ''Earthrace Conservation'' . He works assisting countries in [[Asia]], [[Central America]] and [[Africa]] with [[Fishery|fisheries]] [[enforcement]] and [[anti-poaching]]. He is the holder of the [[world record]] for [[Circumnavigation|circumnavigating]] the globe in his powerboat ''Earthrace'', a [[Wave-piercing hull|wavepiercing]] [[trimaran]] powered with [[biofuel]]s. ''Earthrace'' was renamed the ''[[Ady Gil]]'' in 2009 and Captain Bethune sailed it in [[Antarctica]] for [[Sea Shepherd Conservation Society]]<sup>[1]</sup> to disrupt [[Japan]]ese [[whaling]] activities. The vessel was involved in a [[collision]] with a Japanese whaling vessel. He subsequently boarded the whaling vessel the ''Shonan Maru 2'' and presented the [[Sea captain|Captain]] with an invoice for the ''Ady Gil''. Captain Bethune was taken back to Japan and charged with a number of offenses related to his [[anti-whaling]] activities and received a [[suspended sentence]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/10534373|title=Whaling activist Bethune given suspended sentence|date=2010-07-07|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-08-09|language=en-GB}}</ref>
In 2012, Captain. Bethune started ''Earthrace Conservation'' that works on [[Conservation biology|conservation]] and [[Environmental policy|environmental]] campaigns. His team consists of former [[military]] personnel, and they are involved in [[Fishery|fisheries]] [[enforcement]], [[anti-poaching]], and stopping [[wildlife smuggling]]. Many of the missions have been filmed and made into the TV Series ''The Operatives'' that has now aired in around 90 countries. More recently his work has involved training government teams on [[coast]]al and offshore [[surveillance]], [[Fishery|fisheries]] [[enforcement]], and [[maritime security]].
Captain Bethune is currently developing ''Earthrace-2'', a 60m [[trimaran]] for [[Conservation biology|conservation]] work, fisheries enforcement and [[Scientific method|scientific research]].
==Personal life and early career== Captain Bethune grew up in Hamilton West, [[New Zealand]] as one of five children. He completed a [[Master of Business Administration]] at the [[Macquarie Graduate School of Management]], [[Bachelor of Science]] at the [[University of Waikato]], and a [[Bachelor of Engineering]] at the [[University of Auckland]].<ref name="NZ Herald 2006-04-08">{{Cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/personalities/news/article.cfm?c_id=72&objectid=10376534&pnum=0|title=Mad sailor Peter Bethune not a nutcase|last=Hewitson|first=Michele|date=8 April 2006|work=The New Zealand Herald|accessdate=26 March 2010}}</ref> He has two daughters with his wife, Sharyn, his high school sweetheart,<ref name="NZ Herald 2010-02-20">{{Cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/eloise-gibson/news/article.cfm?a_id=366&objectid=10627312&pnum=0|title=Love him or hate him, he's effective, says activist's wife|last=Gibson |first=Eloise|date=20 February 2010|work=The New Zealand Herald|accessdate=12 April 2010}}</ref> from whom he [[divorce]]d in 2009.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Home Alone|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/sunday-star-times/features/3725222/Home-alone|accessdate=25 May 2010|newspaper=Sunday Star Times|date=23 May 2010|author=Wall, Tony|author2=Coldicott, Nicholas}}</ref>
He began his career as an [[Hydrocarbon exploration|oil exploration]] [[engineer]] for [[Schlumberger]] Wireline Services{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} and worked in the [[North Sea]] and [[Libya]].<ref name="NZ Herald 2004-07-31"/> In 1997, he co-founded CamSensor Technologies.<ref name="NZ Herald 2004-07-31"/> The company manufactures automated camera systems for controlling robots used in complex tasks such as cutting up and grading meat carcasses.<ref name="NZ Herald 2004-07-31"/> He later moved to [[Sydney]] to establish a subsidiary there.<ref name="NZ Herald 2004-07-31">{{Cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=3581473|title=Green speedster aims for record|last=Collins|first=Simon|date=31 July 2004|work=The New Zealand Herald|accessdate=10 April 2010}}</ref>
His entry into conservation started when he wrote a 20,000-word paper titled "Alternative Fuels for Road Transport" while pursuing his [[Master of Business Administration]] degree from [[Macquarie University]] in 2004<ref name="NZ Herald 2004-07-31"/> He concluded that hydrogen as a fuel was a dead-end, but that [[biofuel]]s such as [[biodiesel]] and [[Ethanol fuel|ethanol]] could become mainstream in use. He also predicted the battery electric vehicle could eventually replace the combustion engine in terms of road transport.<ref name="NZ Herald 2004-07-31" /> For leisure, Captain Bethune enjoys [[camping]], [[Scuba diving|scuba]], [[freediving]], [[kayaking]], and [[CrossFit|crossfit]]. He told a reporter for ''[[The New Zealand Herald]]'': "I've come from a very unusual background to be a [[conservation movement|conservationist]]."<ref name="NZ Herald 2006-04-08"/>
==Captain of Earthrace== [[File:MY Earthrace in Fiordland.jpg|thumb|MY Earthrace in Dusky Sound, Fiordland, New Zealand]] Based on his research at [[Macquarie Graduate School of Management]], Captain Bethune set out to prove that hydrocarbon fuels could be replaced by sustainable [[bio-fuels]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.powerboat-world.com/Earthrace---New-Record-Round-the-World-in-60-days/45820/arc|author=Kothe, Rob|title=Earthrace - New Record Round the World in 60 days|publisher=PowerboatWorld.com|date=27 June 2008}}</ref> He had ''Earthrace'' designed by [[LOMOcean Design]] and built in order to break the world record for a [[circumnavigation]] of the globe by a powerboat in hopes that it would call attention to the viability of [[biodiesel]] as an alternative fuel. He mortgaged his New Zealand home and financed the building in the hopes of recouping the expenses from sponsorship. He declined a $4 million sponsorship from a company that would have required them to use regular diesel.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://galvestondailynews.com/story.lasso?ewcd=58e7dcb0ac291c6a|title=Crew hopes biodiesel boat will break record|last=McDonald|first=Sara|date=18 December 2006|work=[[The Galveston County Daily News]]|accessdate=12 April 2010}}</ref> [[File:Helm of Earthrace.jpg|thumb|The helm of Earthrace resembled more a race car than a boat]] [[File:MY Earthrace during record setting voyage in 2008.jpg|thumb|MY Earthrace offshore from Mexico in her record setting voyage in 2008]] His first attempt began in Barbados on 10 March 2007. He encountered significant delays due to issues with the propellers and other mechanical problems.<ref name="NZ Herald 2007-06-03">{{Cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/environment/news/article.cfm?c_id=39&objectid=10443330|title=Earthrace highlights green cause|last=Griffin|first=Peter|date=3 June 2007|work=The New Zealand Herald|accessdate=28 March 2010}}</ref> On the night of 19 March, while around {{Convert|22|km|mi|0}} offshore from [[Guatemala]], ''Earthrace'' collided with a local fishing boat.<ref name="Collision">{{Cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/section/1/story.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10429738|accessdate=6 January 2010|title=Earthrace chief in court over tragedy|newspaper=[[New Zealand Herald]]|publisher=[[APN News & Media]]|date=20 March 2007}}</ref> The crew was absolved of any responsibility after a 10-day investigation during which they were held in custody under armed guard in the [[military]] compound in [[Puerto Quetzal]]. The delays prevented them from completing the circumnavigation in record time using their original start location. ''The'' crew took ''Earthrace'' to [[San Diego]] where they made repairs. They then restarted their record attempt, leaving [[San Diego]] on 7 April 2007. Once they rounded [[Aceh]] in [[Indonesia]] and started crossing the [[Indian Ocean]] the vessel encountered significant bad weather in the first [[Monsoon of South Asia|monsoon]] of the season. The [[Monsoon of South Asia|monsoon]] remained with them all the way to [[Salalah]] in [[Oman]]. The vessel passed through the [[Suez Canal]], then when getting close to [[Spain]], crew discovered a structural failure around the depth [[transducer]]. Bethune said the "failure was a result of the constant pounding in crossing the [[Indian Ocean|Indian Ocean".]] Crew made temporary repairs and headed out to cross the Atlantic, however the repairs failed and Earthrace limped back to port in [[Málaga]], [[Spain]].<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.intrepidmagazine.co.nz/articles/6/earthrace/|title=Intrepid Adventure New Zealand - Earthrace: The man and the machine|publisher=Intrepidmagazine.co.nz|accessdate=27 May 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100526215710/http://www.intrepidmagazine.co.nz/articles/6/earthrace/|archivedate=26 May 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Bethune decided to abandon the attempt. Captain Bethune returned to [[New Zealand]] to recover from what he said was "a brutal ordeal". After meeting with some of his original sponsors, he assembled a new team. The vessel was repaired and departed from [[Sagunto, Spain]], in another record attempt on 1 March 2008. The second record attempt also suffered a large number of setbacks. The auto-pilot system failed in the [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic]] crossing. This was repaired in [[Puerto Rico]]. There was a general strike in [[Panama Canal]] causing 3 days in delays waiting to transit the [[canal]]. In the leg between [[Hawaii]] and [[Marshall Islands]], there was a problem with the [[Common-rail injection|common rail injection]] system, which was repaired in [[Majuro]]. The crew then had their biggest setback in Palau, when ''Earthrace'' hit a submerged log a few nautical miles offshore. The vessel limped back into [[Palau]] with extensive damage. A list of problems included a bent [[Drive shaft|driveshaft]], [[propeller]] damage, smashed P-Bracket, smashed engine mounts, broken [[Transmission (mechanics)|gearbox]], [[rudder]] damage, and a 5 meter gouge down the [[Port and starboard|starboard]] side of the composite hull. Crew determined it would be almost impossible to repair the vessel quickly in [[Palau]]. They made temporary repairs and ran on one engine to [[Singapore]]. On arrival, the initial assessment was repairs would take at least 2 weeks, which would make the record almost impossible to get. Marine salvage company [http://www.posh.com.sg/ Posh Semco] offered to help with haul-out, and the vessel was pulled from the water. Crew worked around the clock for 3 days. ''Earthrace'' was put back into the water with what Captain Bethune described as "the ugliest composite repair" he'd ever seen. Crew continued on their voyage towards their finish line in [[Spain]]. <ref name="NZ Herald 2006-04-08" /> Captain Bethune finished at the Spanish port of [[Sagunto]] on 27 June. The journey was completed in 60 days, 23 hours and 49 minutes, beating the former record by over two weeks.<ref name="Popular Mechanics 2007-06">{{Cite journal|url=http://www.popularmechanics.co.za/content/outside/singlepage.asp?fid=871&pno=1|title=Earthrace!|date=June 2007|journal=[[Popular Mechanics]]|publisher=[[Hearst Corporation]]|accessdate=6 January 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100122011707/http://www.popularmechanics.co.za/content/outside/singlepage.asp?fid=871&pno=1|archivedate=22 January 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://dsc.discovery.com/news/2008/06/27/earthrace-biodiesel.html|author=Irene Klotz|title=Biofuel Boat Sets Round-the-World Record|publisher=Discovery News|date=27 June 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101010134054/http://dsc.discovery.com/news/2008/06/27/earthrace-biodiesel.html|archivedate=10 October 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Captain Bethune later confessed the reason they missed the record on the first attempt was his leadership was poor. He said the real difference in the second successful attempt was he did a better job in making decisions and running the team. He also claimed his team had been outstanding in Singapore. They had achieved a small [[miracle]] in getting ''Earthrace'' repaired so quickly, in very challenging circumstances.
==Earthrace Promotional Tour==
When ''Earthrace'' was first launched in 2006, Captain Bethune took her on a promotional tour around [[New Zealand]]. The vessel was given a Maori blessing in [[Raglan, New Zealand|Raglan]] before she left to cross the [[Pacific Ocean|Pacific]]. Over the next three years, the team took the boat to 186 cities around the world, opening the boat to [[school]] groups, [[public]], media, and sponsors. Through this time, over 250,000 people walked aboard the vessel. Captain Bethune used the tour to promote awareness of alternative fuels such as biodiesel.<ref name="Dominion Post 2009-04-17">{{Cite news|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/dominion-post/wellington/2340570/Afloat-on-a-stylish-green-prison|title=Afloat on a stylish green prison|date=17 April 2009|work=The Dominion Post|accessdate=11 April 2010}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
As a [[publicity stunt]], Bethune underwent [[liposuction]] surgery in order to convert body fat into fuel.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Technology/Earthrace-Launches-World-Record-Attempt/Article/20071231297421?lpos=Technology_Article_Related_Content_Region_1&lid=ARTICLE_1297421_Earthrace_Launches_World_Record_Attempt|title=Earthrace Launches World Record Attempt|date=18 December 2007|accessdate=12 April 2010|publisher=Sky News}}</ref> A cosmetic surgeon removed around 50ml of fat from his back. The surgeon provided a further 10 liters of human fat from 2 other patients. Bethune converted this into 7 liters of biodiesel in his kitchen at home. Bethune ran the fuel in his vessel, claiming the 7 liters of fuel ran the boat for an estimated 8 nautical miles.<ref name="NZ Herald 2006-04-08" />
==Captain of Ady Gil== [[File:Ady Gil 2.jpg|thumb|right|''Ady Gil'', [[Hobart]], [[Australia]], 16 December 2009.]]
After touring ports around the globe, the ''Earthrace'' was put on sale for $3 million and Captain Bethune considered using it to interfere with [[Japanese whaling]] in the [[Southern Ocean]] if a buyer could not be found.<ref name="Dominion Post 2009-04-17"/><ref name="ABC 2009-06-09">{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2009/06/29/2611146.htm|title=Stealth boat to take on Japanese whalers|last=Brown|first=Bill|date=9 June 2009|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=11 April 2010}}</ref> Hollywood production-house owner Ady Gil purchased the boat and ''Earthrace'' was renamed after him on 17 October 2009.<ref name="CMSwhale">{{Cite news|url=http://features.csmonitor.com/globalnews/2009/10/29/south-park-puts-spotlight-on-paul-watson-and-his-whale-wars/|title=South Park puts spotlight on Paul Watson and his "Whale Wars"|last=Murphy|first=Dan|date=29 October 2009|publisher=[[The Christian Science Monitor]]|accessdate=3 November 2009|quote=...on Oct. 17 (2009) the organisation formally unveiled it's new weapon: The Ady Gil.}}</ref> Gil leased the ship to [[Sea Shepherd Conservation Society]] for $1 / year to pursue [[Japan]]ese [[Whaling|whalers]] in Antarctica. Captain Bethune was put in charge of the refit and was to captain the vessel in its [[anti-whaling]] activities.<ref name="The Age 2009-12-01">{{Cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/national/wail-for-whales-stealth-boat-to-blast-japanese-20091130-k18l.html|title=Wail for whales: stealth boat to blast Japanese|last=Darby|first=Andrew|date=1 December 2009|work=The Age|accessdate=11 April 2010 | location=Melbourne}}</ref><ref name="STREET FIGHT">{{Cite news| title=Street Fight on the High Seas| work=[[The New Yorker]]| date=12 January 2010| url=http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/newsdesk/2010/01/sea-shepherd.html| accessdate=16 January 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/world/3441287/Kiwi-anti-whaling-activist-arrested-in-Japan-report|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130112095137/http://www.stuff.co.nz/world/3441287/Kiwi-anti-whaling-activist-arrested-in-Japan-report|dead-url=yes|archive-date=12 January 2013|title=Kiwi anti-whaling activist arrested in Japan|publisher=Fairfax Media|date=12 March 2010}}</ref> Captain Bethune said before the operation: "I'm a conservationist. One of the things I've learned on ''Earthrace'' is stand up for stuff you believe in. Year after year the Japanese go down there and nothing seems to change... If they want to go amping things up a bit, then bring it on."<ref name="ABC 2009-06-09"/> His wife later told the press that he first became alarmed by the state of the oceans when skippering the vessel during the record attempts.<ref name="NZ Herald 2010-02-20"/>
On 6 January 2010 the ''Ady Gil'' was involved in a collision with the Japanese whaling vessel {{MV|Shōnan Maru 2}} in the Southern Ocean when the ''Shonan Maru No 2'' hit it, and the ''Ady Gil'' was subsequently abandoned.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/asia/172123/activists-urge-australia-to-charge-japanese-whalers|title=Activists urge Australia to charge Japanese whalers|publisher=Bangkok Post|date=19 March 2010}}</ref> An investigation into the collision by the [[Australian Maritime Safety Authority]] (AMSA) was inconclusive in assigning blame for the collision. AMSA was unable to verify claims made by Sea Shepherd, while the Japanese government declined to participate with the investigation saying any information it had might be needed for an inquiry by its own authorities.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-national/inquiry-into-ady-gil-crash-inconclusive-20100508-ukx4.html|title=Inquiry into Ady Gil crash inconclusive|publisher=News.smh.com.au|date=8 May 2010|accessdate=27 May 2010}}</ref> However [[Maritime New Zealand]] investigators released a report that the ''Ady Gil'' was the stand on vessel and had right of way. The ''Shonan Maru No 2'' was the port side vessel, and the overtaking vessel, and under both circumstances, had an obligation to keep well clear of the Ady Gil. The report did conclude however that the captains of both the ''Ady Gil'' and the whaler, the ''Shonan Maru No 2'', "were partly responsible for either contributing to, or failing to respond to the 'close quarters' situation that led to the [[collision]]".<ref>http://www.maritimenz.govt.nz/adygil/#media</ref>
==Arrest, trial, and conviction==
On 15 February 2010 in the middle of the night, Captain Bethune attempted to board the ''Shōnan Maru 2'' from a jet ski. On his first attempt he fell into the water, and was recovered by his Engineer, Larry Routledge a few minutes later. On his second attempt, Captain Bethune managed to climb between the anti-boarding spikes and onto the side of the hull, where he then cut through the protective netting and clambered aboard. The purpose of the boarding was to conduct a [[citizen's arrest]] on her captain, Hiroyuki Komiya, alleging attempted murder, and to present a claim for $3 million for the ramming of his vessel. Captain Bethune was not successful in arresting Komiya, nor did he receive any compensation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/environment/whale-watch/tokyos-angry-reception-for-antiwhaling-activist-20100312-q46s.html|title=Tokyo's angry reception for anti-whaling activist|author=Robin What I can do is make sure the person is being treated fairly."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-world/nz-offer-to-support-antiwhaler-at-trial-20100524-w7hj.html|title=NZ offer to support anti-whaler at trial|publisher=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=24 May 2010}}</ref>
On 4 June, in what was later claimed by [[Paul Watson]] to be a legal strategy on the part of Sea Shepherd,<ref name="smh strategy">{{Cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/environment/whale-watch/bethune-welcome-to-rejoin-sea-shepherd-watson-20100708-101m5.html|title=Bethune welcome to rejoin Sea Shepherd: Watson|date=8 July 2010|publisher=Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=13 July 2010}}</ref> Sea Shepherd announced that it was no longer going to be formally associated with Captain Bethune since a set of bow and arrows was on the ''Ady Gil'' during the anti-whaling operation. The group stressed that the weapon was not intended to be used against any person, and Captain Bethune previously had stated to [[Animal Planet]] cameras during ''[[Whale Wars]]'' filming that he intended to use the bow and arrows to spoil [[whale meat]] for commercial use.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Sea Shepherd casts Bethune adrift|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/06/08/2921909.htm?section=justin|accessdate=8 June 2010|publisher=ABC News|date=8 June 2010}}</ref><ref name="tools & tactics">{{Cite web|title=Tools and Tactics of Whale Wars|url=http://animal.discovery.com/videos/whale-wars-tools-tactics/|accessdate=13 July 2010|publisher=Animal Planet|date=}}</ref> Captain Bethune later said he felt betrayed by Sea Shepherd abandoning him. He claimed Watson had agreed to the bow and arrow being taken aboard <ref>{{Cite news|title=Sea Shepherd cuts ties with whale activist Pete Bethune|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/world/asia_pacific/10266219.stm|accessdate=8 June 2010|publisher=BBC News|date=8 June 2010}}</ref> Sea Shepherd said it would continue to support Bethune during the trial in Japan.
On 7 July, Pete Bethune was convicted of disruption of business, destruction of property, boarding a vessel without due cause, assault and possession of a knife without due cause<ref name="guardian.co.uk">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jul/07/peter-bethune-sea-shepherd-sentence|title=Sea Shepherd man sentenced for whaler assault|last=McCurry|first=Justin|date=7 July 2010|work=The Guardian|location=London}}</ref> and given a two-year suspended sentence.<ref name="TVNZ_3632066">{{cite news |url=http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/bethune-gets-suspended-sentence-3632066 |title=Japan deports Kiwi whaling protester |date=7 July 2010 |work=[[Television New Zealand]] |accessdate=2 November 2011}}</ref><ref>[[Kyodo News]], "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20100703a6.html Bethune writing book about activism]", ''-[[Japan Times]]'', 3 July 2010.</ref> Bethune was deported to New Zealand on 9 July.. Bethune held a press conference upon returning to New Zealand. He told reporters: "My trial in Japan represents a miscarriage in justice. Not because I stood before that court, but because the captain of the ''Shōnan Maru 2'' did not."<ref>{{Cite news|title=Bethune calls Japanese trial miscarriage of justice; blasts NZ gov't|url=http://www.japantoday.com/category/crime/view/bethune-calls-japanese-trial-miscarriage-of-justice-blasts-nz-govt|accessdate=15 August 2010|publisher=Japan Today|date=12 July 2010}}</ref> He also called the New Zealand Government a "lap dog"<ref>{{Cite news|title=Bethune slams Govt as 'lap dog'|url=http://www.3news.co.nz/Bethune-slams-Govt-as-lap-dog/tabid/1160/articleID/165392/Default.aspx#top|accessdate=15 August 2010|publisher=3 News|date=12 July 2010}}</ref> for what he considered a lack of backbone in standing up to Japan over whaling.
==Disassociation from Sea Shepherd== Captain Bethune disassociated himself from Sea Shepherd by posting an open letter on his Facebook page on 4 October 2010, condemning the organization and its leader Paul Watson as "dishonest" and "morally bankrupt". According to his letter, he was directed by Paul Watson to sink the ''Ady Gil'' deliberately for PR purposes after the collision with the Japanese whaling ship. He insists that the senior members of Sea Shepherd regularly lie and conspire over the serious matters, detailing many cases in his letter.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.3news.co.nz/Bethune-quits-Sea-Shepherd-over-lies/tabid/1160/articleID/180068/Default.aspx|author=Speedy, Juliet|title=Bethune quits Sea Shepherd over lies|publisher=3 News|date=6 October 2010}}</ref><ref> {{Citation|last=Bethune|first=Pete|title=My alleged suing of Sea Shepherd for $500,000|date=22 November 2011|url=https://www.facebook.com/note.php?note_id=10150465988955867|accessdate=23 March 2012}} </ref>
Based largely on testimony from Captain Bethune and former Sea Shepherd Bob Barker Captain, Chuck Swift, Ady Gil successfully sued Sea Shepherd for the deliberate abandonment of his vessel in Antarctica. In siding will Mr. Gil, the arbitrator awarded him compensatory damages of $500,000 plus interest from January 8, 2010 forward.
In characterizing testimony for the suit, the arbitrator was particularly harsh on Paul Watson; finding the Sea Shepherd founder in some instances to "be highly evasive, internally contradictory, or at odds with his own prior written statements, and in certain areas simply lacking the basic indicia of genuineness that instinctively inspires confidence and trust."<ref name="ecorazzi.com">{{cite web|title=Judge-rules sea shepherd wrongfully sank whale wars vessel|url=http://www.ecorazzi.com/2015/09/25/judge-rules-sea-shepherd-wrongfully-sank-whale-wars-vessel/|website=Ecorazzi|accessdate=21 December 2016}}</ref> As for Gil, the arbitrator stated his "testimony appeared genuine in intent if somewhat fuzzy in detail, and perhaps colored in hindsight by strong emotions of betrayal on the part of those in whom he had placed a perhaps naïve degree of trust."<ref name="ecorazzi.com"/>
==Earthrace Conservation== Captain Bethune founded his own [[Conservation biology|conservation]] organization in 2011, Earthrace Conservation.<ref>[http://www.earthraceconservation.org/ Earthrace Conservation Homepage].</ref> and he assists government agencies with [[Illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing|Illegal Fishing]], [[Wildlife]] [[Poaching]] and other [[Environmental crime|Environmental Crimes]]. It has [[Nonprofit organization|non-profit]] or [[Charitable organization|charity]] status in [[New Zealand]], [[United States|USA]] and [[United Kingdom|UK]]. He also has a Television Show "[[The Operatives]]" that follows his team's work. Captain Bethune employs former military personnel that undertake the missions.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://earthraceconservation.org/about-earthrace-conservation/|title=About Earthrace Conservation and how it works, so you can be involved, donate, sponsor.|website=earthraceconservation.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-07}}</ref> In 2013, Captain Bethune was running fisheries patrols in the [[Guanacaste Province|Guanacaste]] region of [[Costa Rica]]. His team had been flying a Skylark [[military]] [[Unmanned combat aerial vehicle|drone]] at night over the surrounding waters when they detected a vessel the ''Amelita'', allegedly fishing inside a [[Marine protected area|Marine Protected Areas]]. Bethune launched his patrol boat from shore and approached the ''Amelita''. The team covertly filmed the ''Amelita'' engaged in ''shrimp trawling,'' following her for 7 hours. On daybreak, crew of the ''Amelita'' pulled in their trawl nets. Bethune boarded the vessel, filmed the catch, and interviewed the Captain, who claimed to be the President of the Commercial Fisherman's Association in [[Puntarenas]]. Bethune handed the evidence over to a local NGO and [[Costa Rica]]n [[Authority|authorities]] who [[Prosecutor|prosecuted]] the [[Captain]]. Bethune traveled back to Costs Rica in 2015 to provide additional evidence in the [[court case]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://earthraceconservation.org/the-curse-of-illegal-fishing-mission-pirata/|title=THE CURSE OF ILLEGAL FISHING - MISSION PIRATA - Earthrace Conservation|website=earthraceconservation.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-07}}</ref>
In another fishery patrol mission in [[Costa Rica]], Bethune and a crew of 4 took their 7.7m ''Sealegs'' vessel 300 nautical miles offshore to [[Cocos Island]]. The voyage was expected to take just 24 hours, but due to mechanical issues, fuel problems and bad weather, ended up at 72 hours. Bethune later claimed "5 broken men arrived on Cocos Island". Several days later on night patrols near the island, Bethune was able to film 7 boats allegedly involved in [[shark finning]] activities inside the [[Cocos Island]] [[Marine protected area|Marine Protected Area]]. Evidence of the [[Illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing|illegal]] [[fishing]] was handed over to Authorities who prosecuted Captains of the 7 vessels.<ref name=":0" />
In 2017, Captain Bethune was in the [[Philippines]] training local [[Fishery|fisheries]] [[enforcement]] teams consisting of personnel from [[Navy]] [[special forces]], [[Ministry of Fisheries]] (BFAR) and local [[police]] ([[Bantay Dagat|bantay dagat]]). While on patrols at night on 26 May, they came across a [[Seine fishing|Danish Seine]] [[Trawler (fishing)|trawler]] the "Dan Israel R", allegedly fishing inside [[Municipality|municipal]] waters. Danish Seine is a form of destructive [[bottom trawling]] [[Ban (law)|banned]] in the [[Philippines]]. Crew of the ''Dan Israel R'' were arrested and the vessel escorted into the BFAR impound facility in [[Cavite]]. The vessel was one of 23 in a so-called Alphabet fleet. Owners of the vessel subsequently made a cash offer of 2 million pesos to settle the case.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://earthraceconservation.org/earthrace-helps-capture-pirate-fishing-vessel/|title=Earthrace helps capture Pirate Fishing Vessel - Earthrace Conservation|website=earthraceconservation.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-07}}</ref>
==The Operatives== In 2011 Captain Bethune formed a team of military veterans and specialist civilians to catch and prosecute environmental criminals. This led to the development of ''The Operatives'' TV Series, which so far has run for two seasons and aired in over 90 countries. Units represented in the team included former US Navy [[SEAL Team Six|SEAL Team 6]] and [[SEAL Team 2|2]], [[United States Marine Air-Ground Task Force Reconnaissance|US Marine Recon]], [[United States Army Rangers|US Army Ranger]], [[1st Marine Infantry Parachute Regiment|French 1er]] regiment ([[Special Air Service|SAS]]) and New Zealand [[Paratrooper]]. Each episode involves Captain Bethune and his team examining some form of environmental criminal activity working alongside existing law enforcement units. 18 episodes have been filmed dealing with issues such as [[shark finning]], [[illegal logging]], [[marine protected area]], [[illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing|IUU FIshing,]] [[wildlife smuggling]], [[blast fishing]], [[cyanide fishing]], [[seal hunting]] and [[wildlife]] [[poaching]]<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3990638/The Operatives] ''Internet Movie Database''. Accessed 21 December 2016.</ref>
In July 2012, Captain Bethune and Jack Waldron, a former [[New Zealand]] [[Paratrooper]], entered a [[De Beers|De Beers Diamond]] Mine near [[Lüderitz|Luderitz]] in [[Namibia]]. They were dropped a mile offshore at night by a [[Zodiac Nautic|zodiac]], and swam ashore into the mine area. Over the next four days, Captain Bethune and Waldon avoided security patrols while trying to film the government sanctioned seal clubbing. On the final day, Captain Bethune is hiding in a [[Ghillie suit|gillie suit]] about 50 meters from where a group of seal clubbers have assembled. He films the clubbing of around 500 baby seals. The two men by now are out of food and water, and bad weather prevents them from being picked up by zodiac. They end up hiking out of the diamond mine at night. The video has since been used by various [[animal rights]] and [[Conservation biology|conservation]] groups including [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals|PETA]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://earthraceconservation.org/clubbings-no-adventure-say-80000-seals/|title=Clubbing's No Adventure Say 80,000 Seals - Earthrace Conservation|website=earthraceconservation.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-07}}</ref> It was also used in the first episode of ''The Operatives'' TV Show.<ref>{{Citation|last=Pete Bethune|title=Death in the Diamond Mine - Captain's VLOG 01|date=2014-08-30|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C7ufHbeyUPk&feature=youtu.be|accessdate=2017-08-07}}</ref> In 2015, Captain Bethune presented a 200,000 strong petition to Jake Jacobs, Secretary of the Namibian National Assembly, asking the government to abandon the seal clubbing industry.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.energy100fm.com/?q=content/seal-hunting-activists-handover-petition-na|title=Seal Hunting Activists Hand Over Petitioon|last=Berthune|first=Pete|date=23 Sep 2015|website=100 Energy FM|archive-url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pete_Bethune&action=edit|archive-date=23 Sep 2015|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
In 2013, Captain Bethune assembled his team in [[Costa Rica]] and they ran several missions targeting [[Illegal mining|illegal]] [[gold mining]] in the [[Corcovado National Park]], training and working alongside the [[government]] [[Ministry of Environment, Energy and Telecommunications|MINAE]] forces. Rangers claimed the gold miners were destructive by killing and [[eating]] [[endangered wildlife]], causing extensive [[erosion]] along creek and river beds, and using [[cyanide]] [[poison]] to separate [[gold]] from the [[silt]]. Jack Waldron gathers aerial intelligence by flying a [[Powered paragliding|paramotor]] over the jungle, locating multiple areas of interest. The full team is inserted into the jungle by rappelling from a Bell UH1H helicopter. The campaign led to a number of successful prosecutions and 2 illegal gold mining operations were closed down. There were 2 cases of gunshots being fired at the Rangers by fleeing gold miners.<ref>{{Citation|last=Pete Bethune|title=Jungle Gold Robbers - Captain's VLOG 03|date=2014-08-31|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JkUrCg1lpsg&feature=youtu.be|accessdate=2017-08-07}}</ref>

{{about||the category of art objects produced in West Bengal|Sholapith|the album by Awaz|Shola (album)|people with the given name|Shola (name)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} [[File:Shola.jpg|thumb|500x500px|Sholas in southern [[western ghats]]. These are the [[Montane grasslands and shrublands|tropical and sub-tropical montane forest]].]] '''Sholas''' are the local name for patches of stunted [[Montane grasslands and shrublands|tropical montane forest]] found in valleys amid rolling grassland in the higher montane regions of [[South India]]. These patches of shola forest are found mainly in the valleys and are usually separated from one another by undulating [[montane grassland]]. The shola and grassland together form the shola-grassland complex or mosaic. The word 'Shola' is probably derived from the [[Tamil language]] word cÕlai (சோலை) meaning [[Grove (nature)|grove]].{{citation |url=http://dsal.uchicago.edu/cgi-bin/romadict.pl?query=சோலை&searchhws=yes&table=fabricius |title= J. P. Fabricius's Tamil and English dictionary. 4th ed., rev. and enl.|author=Fabricius, Johann Philipp|publisher=Evangelical Lutheran Mission Pub. House |year=1972 |page=457 }} The shola-forest and grassland complex has been described as a climatic [[climax vegetation]] with forest regeneration and expansion restricted by climatic conditions such as frost or soil characteristics while others have suggested that it may have anthropogenic origins in the burning and removal of forests by early herders and shifting agriculturists.{{cite journal|title=Phytogeography of the South Indian Hill Stations| author=Meher-Homji VM| journal= Bulletin of the Torrey Botanical Club| volume=94| issue=4| year=1997| pages= 230–242| doi=10.2307/2483901}} ==Distribution and origin== [[File:Brahmagirishola.jpg|thumb|300x300px|Shola forest interspersed in valleys among high altitude grasslands on the [[Brahmagiri (hill)|Brahmagiri Hills]]]] Shola forests are found in the higher altitude hill regions of the Nilgiris, Palni hills, Anamalai hills, Megamalai,Agasthyamalai, Kerala High Ranges [[Idukki district]], the [[Western Ghats]] and associated ranges in the states of [[Karnataka]], [[Kerala]] and [[Tamil Nadu]]. Although generally said to occur above 2000 meters above sea level, shola forests can be found at 1600 meters elevation in many hill ranges (e.g. [[Biligiriranga Hills]]). The origin of the shola forest and grassland complex has been the subject of scientific debate. Some early researchers suggested that the floristic composition represents a stable final state or climax vegetation. This stability being maintained by climatic conditions such as frost which allow the grass to grow but kill off any forest seedlings.{{cite journal|author=Ranganathan, C. R. |year= 1938| title= Studies in the ecology of the shola grass-land vegetation of the Nilgiri Plateau| journal= Indian Forester |volume= 64|pages=523–541}} Others have suggested that the grassland may have been created and maintained by early pastoralists and point out that fire has a major role in the maintenance of the grassland.{{cite journal|author= Bor, N. L. |year=1938|title= The vegetation of the Nilgiris| journal= Indian Forester |volume=64|pages=600–609}} There is evidence for both and several features of the forest trees and the grasslands have been considered and debated. Pollen analysis from bogs in the Nilgiris suggest that the complex of grassland and forest existed 35,000 years ago, long before human impact began.{{cite journal| journal= Géographie physique et Quaternaire| year= 1997| volume= 51| issue= 3|pages=415–426| title=Etude palynologique d'un nouveau sondage dans les marai de Sandynallah (Massif des Nilgiri, Sud-ouest de L'Inde)|author1=Sutra, J-P |author2=R Bonnefille |author3=M. Fontugne |lastauthoramp=yes | url=http://www.erudit.org/revue/gpq/1997/v51/n3/033140ar.pdf| doi=10.7202/033140ar}} Long term studies on the dynamic processes of vegetation change continue.{{cite journal| title=The montane grasslands of the Western Ghats, India: Community ecology and conservation| author1=Thomas, S. M. Thomas| author2=M. W. Palmer| lastauthoramp=yes| journal=Community Ecology| volume=8| issue=1| pages=67–73| year=2007| doi=10.1556/ComEc.8.2007.1.9| url=http://botany.okstate.edu/people_research/Palmer/Articles/Ghats.pdf| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720020622/http://botany.okstate.edu/people_research/Palmer/Articles/Ghats.pdf | archivedate=20 July 2011| df=dmy-all}}{{cite journal|author1=Shibu Jose |author2=A. Sreepathy |author3=B. Mohan Kumar |author4=V.K. Venugopal | title= Structural, floristic and edaphic attributes of the grassland-shola forests of Eravikulam in peninsular India| journal= Forest Ecology and Management| volume=65| issue=2&3|pages=279–291 |year=1994| doi= 10.1016/0378-1127(94)90176-7}}{{cite journal| chapter= Andisols of the Nilgiri highlands: new insight into their classification, age and genesis|author1=Caner, L |author2=Bourgeon G |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Sahyadri : The Great Escarpment of the Indian Subcontinent (Patterns of Landscape Development in the Western Ghats)|editors=Y. Gunnell and B.P. Radhakrishna. Memoirs Geological Society of India, Bangalore, 2001, No. 47|year=2001|publisher=Geological Society of India|pages=905–918.|url=http://hal.cirad.fr/docs/00/25/94/35/PDF/Caner_Memoir-Geological-Society-India_2001.pdf}} ==Fauna== Due to their isolation, altitude and evergreen character, shola forests are home to many [[threatened]] and [[endemic (ecology)|endemic]] [[species]].{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} Some of the species found here have close relatives only in the distant evergreen forests of [[Northeast India]] and [[Southeast Asia]]. Some others are found nowhere else in the world. [[File:Shola flower.jpg|thumb|''[[Exacum]] bicolor'', a shola grassland plant]] The [[Western Ghats]] are one of the globally recognized [[biodiversity hotspot]]s. Among the many larger animals inhabiting a shola-grassland mosaic are [[tiger]]s and [[leopard]]s, [[Asian elephant|elephant]]s and [[gaur]]. The endangered [[Nilgiri tahr]] (an Asian goat-antelope) is endemic to the shola-grassland, and its range is now restricted to a 400-km stretch of shola-grassland mosaic, from the [[Nilgiri Hills]] to the [[Agasthyamalai Hills]].Misra & Johnsingh 1998 [[Laughingthrush]]es, [[Nilgiri woodpigeon]]s, [[Shortwing (bird)|shortwing]]s, and some of the endemic flycatchers (black-and-orange and Nilgiri verditer) are some of the 300+ species of birds that inhabit this area. The area shows high endemicity and is rivalled only by the forests in northeast India; 35 percent of the plants, 42 percent of the [[fish]]es, 48 percent of the [[reptile]]s, and 75 percent of the [[amphibian]]s that live in these rain forests are endemic species.Govt. of India 1997{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} == Flora == At least 25 types of trees are present in the major sholas of the [[Nilgiri Hills]].Premalatha S., Sanil R. & Franklin Charles Jose. 2009. Shola trees in the upper Nilgiris of Western Ghats. ''Journal of Basic & Applied Biology'' 3(3&4),97-102. The dominant trees in this type of forest are ''[[Michelia#Michelia species|Michelia niligarica]]'', ''[[Bischofia javanica]]'' (bishop wood), ''Calophyllum tomentosa'', ''[[Cedrela toona]]'' (Indian mahogany), ''[[Eugenia]]'' (myrtle) spp., ''[[Ficus glomerata]]'' (atti or cluster fig tree or gular fig tree) and ''[[Mallotus (plant)|Mallotus]]'' spp. Shola forests have an upper storey of small trees, generally ''Pygeum gardneri'', ''[[Schefflera]] racemosa'', ''[[Linociera]] ramiflora'', ''[[Syzygium]]'' spp., ''[[Rhododendron#Species|Rhododendron nilgiricum]]'', ''[[Mahonia]] nepalensis'', ''[[Elaeocarpus]] recurvatus'', ''[[Ilex]] denticulata'', ''[[Michelia]] nilagirica'', ''[[Actinodaphne]] bourdellonii'', and ''[[Litsea]] wightiana''. Below the upper story is a low understory and a dense shrub layer. There is a thick concentration of mosses growing on the understory and many ferns in the sunlit narrow transition to grassland. Shola forests are interspersed with [[montane grassland]]s, characterized by frost- and fire-resistant [[grass]] species like ''Chrysopogon zeylanicus'', ''Cymbopogon flexuosus'', ''Arundinella ciliata'', ''Arundinella mesophylla'', ''Arundinella tuberculata'', ''Themeda tremula'', and ''Sehima nervosum''. ==Threats== Invasive [[Introduced species]] are a serious threat to this high altitude ecosystem. Some, like [[Acacia mearnsii]] and [[Eucalyptus globulus]] are the consequence of commercial plantation and afforestation drives. Other threatening invasives include [[Lantana camara]] and [[Ageratina adenophora]]. {{citation |url=http://www.akademiai.com/content/w7613053k523056r/fulltext.pdf |title= The montane grasslands of the Western Ghats, India: Community ecology and conservation |work=Community Ecology |author1=S. M. Thomas |author2=M. W. Palmer |lastauthoramp=yes |publisher=Akademia Kiado, Budapest |year=2007 |page=8(1): 67–73 |accessdate=20 July 2016 }} ==Conservation== [[File:Shola forests.jpg|thumb|240px|left]]Periodic fires have been considered to help maintain the grassland, however excessive burning has led to a shrinkage of forest patches and the growth of [[invasive species]].Rawat, G.S, P.V. Karunakaran, and V.K Uniyal. 2003. Shola grasslands of the Western Ghats: conservation status and management needs. ''ENVIS Bulletin on Grassland Ecosystems and Agroforestry'' 1(1):57-64. [http://envis.iifm.ac.in/EB/Sholagrass.pdf 112 kB PDF] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050302152745/http://envis.iifm.ac.in/EB/Sholagrass.pdf |date=2 March 2005 }} The shola biome have a high water retention capacity and exists as the precious source of the water for the high altitude organisms are the origin of many streams and rivers in the Western Ghats. ==Gallery== {| |[[File:Shola Grasslands and forests in the Kudremukh National Park, Western Ghats, Karnataka.jpg|thumb|Shola-Grasslands complex in the [[Kudremukh National Park]]]] |[[File:Shola-grass-mountain-Grass HillsNP.JPG|thumb|160px|Shola, grass and mountain en route to Grass Hills,
[[Indira Gandhi National Park]]]] | |} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{commons category|Shola}} [[Category:Tropical and subtropical moist broadleaf forests]] [[Category:Indomalaya ecozone]] [[Category:Ecoregions of India]]

{{unreferenced|date=March 2015}} [[Image:Foamfixer.jpg|thumb|right|Foam fixer pump used to draw silicone foam individual components, then mix them at the nozzle and dispense into desired location.]] [[Image:Silicone foam sakno1.jpg|thumb|right|Silicone foam having been dispensed into hole in a wall, above a door.]] '''Silicone foam''' is a [[synthetic rubber]] product used in [[gasket]]ing, sheets and [[firestop]]s. It is available in solid, cured form as well as in individual liquid components for field installations.
==Uses== *[[Gasket]]s *Sheets *High temperature tubes for [[autoclave]]s *[[Firestop]]s *[[Surfactant]]s
==Vulcanisation== When the constituent components of silicone foam are mixed together, they evolve [[hydrogen]] gas, which causes bubbles to form within the rubber, as it changes from liquid to solid. This results in an outward pressure. Temperature and humidity can influence the rate of expansion.
==See also== *[[Firestop]] *[[Gerald W. Brown]] *[[Vulcanization|Vulcanisation]] *[[Rubber]]

A '''spill pallet''' is a [[Bunding|bunded]] secondary containment item that is designed to hold containers of [[oil]] and [[fuel]]s, typically in either a {{convert|205|L|impgal USgal|adj=on}} [[drum]] or in an [[intermediate bulk container]]. It is called a 'secondary containment item' because it is designed to catch the leaks and spill of the container's contents which rest upon it.
The spill pallets can come in a variety of sizes to accommodate multiple containers.
==UK Legislation== In the UK, a container of oil or fuel cannot be stored outside unless it is bundled in a secondary containment item (Oil Storage Regulations 2001). This means that if the container of oil leaks, it will be contained within the [[Bunding|bund]]. The secondary containment item must be able to hold 110% of the largest container above.<ref>[http://www.environment-agency.gov.uk/business/topics/oil/default.aspx For further information on Legislation and Regulations]</ref>
If a person were to store 4 x 205-litre drums on the sump pallet, the sump pallet must be able to hold {{convert|225.5|L|impgal USgal}} of oil.
Although there are no laws in the UK stating that a sump pallet must hold 110% of the largest container upon it, it is still considered good practice to do so.
==Materials== Sump pallets can be made in a variety of materials, but due to the nature of the oils or chemicals which will be stored upon it, they are typically made from either [[Stabilizers for polymers|UV stabilised]] [[polyethylene]], or [[steel]] that is [[galvanised]] for further protection from harsher chemicals. Also available in stainless and mild steels.<ref>[http://dolphinmea.com/spill-pallets-uae.html]</ref>
